{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

    | name      = Unknown Speaker

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:24:24.680

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

    | text      = Yeah.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:24:29.720

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:24:46.519
    | text      = I'm less interested in that op-ed than I am in Alex's discussion about some of the more

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:24:50.559
    | text      = the specifics about his belief that the right-left paradigm is an illusion.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:24:54.960
    | text      = I'm a big fan of how he confuses economic systems, government systems, any number of
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:01.279
    | text      = different things.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:02.279
    | text      = Listening to mostly more current episodes of Alex's show from the past five or six years,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:06.960
    | text      = you get the sense that that idea had something to do with political parties.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:11.039
    | text      = Even at the end of the clip, he's making reference to the left and the right having something
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:14.259
    | text      = to do with giving you the illusion of having a choice, which feels like he's talking about
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:18.019
    | text      = voting and political parties.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:19.680
    | text      = Yeah, yeah, yeah.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:20.680
    | text      = However, listening to these 2003 episodes, the concept has sort of taken a different
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:24.440
    | text      = shape.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:25.440
    | text      = Since Alex talks a little bit more about what he actually means back then, and I have to
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:28.759
    | text      = say that I think it's actually way stupider than I thought it was, it actually seems like
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:33.200
    | text      = a political philosophy that's tailor-made to be defined by opposition, which goes a
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:37.839
    | text      = long way toward helping make sense of how the show seemed nonsensical in the Trump era
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:41.480
    | text      = and now.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:43.319
    | text      = When Alex is discussing the illusion of the left-right paradigm, I believe you have to
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:46.440
    | text      = just completely get ideas of liberal or conservative politics out of your head.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:50.579
    | text      = I think Alex is operating on a completely different axis, which is essentially just
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:54.039
    | text      = government is bad.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:56.079
    | text      = It's a pretty childish thing to express as your fundamental political belief, especially
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:25:59.839
    | text      = if you don't have the courage to just come out and be a full-on anarchist.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:03.299
    | text      = If you're against big government, then I'd like to remind you that small government is
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:06.299
    | text      = fucking huge compared to no government.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:10.279
    | text      = Leaving that aside, I want to discuss for a second why Alex's conception of this being
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:13.940
    | text      = the only relevant excess in politics is woefully dumb and not the way to look at the world.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:18.839
    | text      = The sole factor Alex considers in terms of ideology is whether or not something is a
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:22.759
    | text      = system that includes government control of the public, the command and control aspect.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:28.440
    | text      = On the one side of the spectrum, he puts communism, socialism, and fascism as systems with high
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:32.299
    | text      = government control, and at the other end, he has this idealized version of a constitutional
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:36.519
    | text      = republic, which I guess is supposed to have minimal government control, I guess.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:40.200
    | text      = I don't know.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:41.200
    | text      = If that's the only factor that matters, then there should be no difference to Alex between
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:45.680
    | text      = anarcho-capitalism and libertarian socialism.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:49.400
    | text      = Both advocate for the elimination of the centralized state, which would result in a system with
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:53.039
    | text      = even less governmental control over the public than exists in a republic.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:26:57.039
    | text      = Both are conceived around people existing in a stateless world, characterized by voluntarily
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:01.079
    | text      = constructed groups.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:03.240
    | text      = But obviously, these two ideologies have stark differences.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:08.059
    | text      = One of the biggest is their stance on private property.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:11.759
    | text      = Anarcho-capitalists believe the right to private property is essentially the bedrock of society,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:15.119
    | text      = whereas libertarian socialists would view the accumulation of private property to be
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:19.920
    | text      = an instance of the same oppression one might face from the state, just being carried out
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:23.480
    | text      = by a private corporation.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:25.440
    | text      = It's very obvious if you look at these two systems that Alex isn't really being honest
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:28.720
    | text      = about his political preferences.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:30.240
    | text      = If there's two schools of thought which both eschew centralized governmental control, there
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:35.279
    | text      = are still political preferences that Alex has that are on the left-right spectrum.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:40.880
    | text      = Private property is a matter of the left-right spectrum.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:43.160
    | text      = While it's true that most center-left and center-right people tend to agree that private
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:46.839
    | text      = property ownership is good, that's not true when you go to the further ends of the spectrum.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:51.380
    | text      = Further-left ideologies tend to favor communal ownership of private property or democratized
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:55.599
    | text      = workplaces.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:27:56.599
    | text      = Conversely, further-right ideologies tend to believe that private property rights are
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:28:00.839
    | text      = inalienable human rights, and they have no problem with exploitative workplaces because
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:28:04.960
    | text      = employment is a voluntary relationship.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:28:08.079
    | text      = Alex presents himself as being above the left-right paradigm because he wants you to think that
}}
